choices.text:
what is a metonymy?
Metonomy is a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is used to refer to something else that is closely related to it, but not actually the same thing. This type of language use can be very effective at conveying meaning and creating associations between things.

For example, "Washington" could be a metonym for the US government, as the capital city is often seen as representing the entire federal system. Another example would be "Hollywood" being used to refer to the film industry as a whole.

Metonomy can also occur in other languages, such as "Tokyo" being used to mean Japanese culture or "Oxford" for higher education in England. This type of language use is widespread and can be found in many different contexts, from politics to pop culture.
